Topic.Title: a failure of the markets

Message.Msg: Because Wall Street has lost sight of the fact that trust is absolutely essential. The professionals understand behavorial investing. They understand not only that most people will capitulate when a stock moves sufficiently far against them, but how far it needs to be moved into the absurd to make it happen. HFT trading has taken behavioral investing to a new level of absurdity (and there is a reason that most MOMO companies are consumer facing -- it leverages the consumers trust in the brand and experience to pull off the MOMO scam). They constantly churn retail investors who think in terms of fundamentals and, in the process, diminish the number of people who will trust the market and will be willing to put new capital to work there... As I said earlier, the dynamics described above are used to shake "weak" longs out of extraordinary investments (think AAPL at 312 trading at 15X FE and 12X ex-cash with nearly 100% YOY earnings and revenue growth) and to constantly "weak" shorts out of overvalued scams (like this one). Weak translates to retail/general public/non-institutional. These incessant games on both sides violate most people's sense of justice and fairness and therein lies the rub. Ultimately, people have a well developed intuitive sense of relative value because we as individuals make microeconomic tradeoffs every day. The nonsensical nature of the relative valuations in the marketplace is what is leading to the breakdown of trust and the incessant outflows of the market (institutional money may rotate from bonds, but retail will continue scale out, leaving whatever institution doesn't sell holding the bag....). The cult of equities is dying because the big boys choose short term trading profit over engendering the public trust, without which the financial markets will enter into sure secular decline (people will invest in homes, physical assets and local private companies... money will flow to where trust and tangible value resides). When the big boys decide to absorb some short term pain and let these scams die, then and only then will the financial markets regain the trust of the public and become healthy again. That is when money flow will return and the markets might have hope. to date, they haven't shown the willingness to do the right thing and realign valuations, so Sybs might prove right with his predictions for the S&P.
